Both ab-plane and c-axis thermal conductivities (kab and kc) of lightly doped La22xSrxCuO4 ~LSCO! and Figure 3 summarizes the doping dependences of the size of the high-T peak in kab(T) @deﬁned by the difference between the peak value and kab(100 K)], as well as those of the Ne´el temperature TN , for the two systems. It is useful to note that the disorder in the Ne´el state induced by Sr doping appears to be detrimental to the mag- non heat transport, because the magnon peak completely dis- appears at x50.01 even though the Ne´el order is still estab- lished at 240 K for this Sr doping.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the Matter 25 (2013) 155701 (8pp) doi:10.1088/0953-8984/25/15/155701 Observation of superconductivity in the intermetallic compound β-IrSn4 Vinh Hung Tran, Zbigniew Bukowski, Piotr Wi´sniewski, Lan Maria Tran and Andrzej J Zaleski Institute of Low Temperature and Structure Research, Polish Academy of Sciences, PO Box 1410, 50-950 Wrocław, Poland E-mail: V.H.Tran@int.pan.wroc.pl Received 4 January 2013, in ﬁnal form 18 February 2013 Published 25 March 2013 Online at stacks.iop.org/JPhysCM/25/155701 Abstract Low-temperature dc-magnetization, ac electrical resistivity and speciﬁc heat measurements were performed on single crystals of the intermetallic compound β-IrSn4. The compound crystallizes in the tetragonal MoSn4-type structure (space group I41/acd) and exhibits superconductivity below Tc = 0.9 ± 0.05 K. Further, the magnitude of the ratios 1Cp/(γnkBTc) = 1.29, 21/(kBTc) = 3.55 and of the electron–phonon coupling λe−ph = 0.5 imply that superconductivity in β-IrSn4 can be ascribed to a s-wave weak coupling regime.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the The bottom panel is the powder x-ray diffraction pattern (small circle symbols) compared to a single crystal diffraction pattern (solid line) obtained using an x-ray beam perpendicular to the 00l plane. ducting with a transition temperature Tc of 0.9 ± 0.05 K. Although the zero-ﬁeld data characterize β-IrSn4 well as a s-wave weakly coupled type-I superconductor in a dirty limit, from an estimation of some thermodynamic parameters we arrive at a conclusion that superconductivity in β-IrSn4 can be ascribed to a type-II superconductor in a clean limit with an assumption of a non-spherical Fermi surface.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the In ﬁgure 2(a) we present the temperature dependence of the magnetization M(T) collected at several magnetic ﬁelds. The data at 1.5 mT reveal a large diamagnetic signal below Tc(1.5 mT) = 0.95 K, indicating a superconducting transition.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the by an Applied Physics Systems Fluxgate Model 150–6325 magnetometer. Low-temperature data shown in the upper inset of ﬁgure 3(a) indicate that the resistivity starts to drop abruptly at 1 K and arrives at zero value at 0.84 K. The critical temperature, Tc, deﬁned as a middle point of the superconducting transition, and the transition width, 1Tc = Tc(90%) −Tc(10%), are determined to be 0.93 K and 0.15 K, respectively.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the In order to get some information on the strength of the electron–phonon coupling we estimate the average electron–phonon coupling constant ¯λe–ph using the McMillan equation [14]: ¯λe–ph = 1.04 + µ∗ln(2D/1.45Tc) (1 −0.62µ∗) ln(2D/1.45Tc) −1.04 (2) where µ∗is the Coulomb pseudopotential, usually assumed to be between 0.1 and 0.15 [14, 15]. For µ∗= 0.15, 2D = 221 K and Tc ≈0.9 K, equation (2) yields ¯λe–ph = 0.5, suggestive of a weak electron–phonon coupling in β-IrSn4.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the The solid line presents the exponential function given by the BCS theory Cel(T) = AγnTc exp(−10/kBT), with A = 12.8 and 10/kB = 1.51 K. The bulk nature of superconductivity in β-IrSn4 is evidenced by a clear peak in the Cp(T)/T dependence. The critical temperature Tc = 0.85 K, taken as the middle point of the 1Cp(T)/T jump, agrees fairly with that deduced from the resistivity.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the A similar behavior has been observed in the type-I superconductors (Sc, Lu)Ga3 [4] and LaRhSi3 [7], thus strongly supporting a type-I superconductivity in β-IrSn4. Second, perhaps most surprisingly, the critical temperature increases a little, up to 0.94 K, on the application of a ﬁeld of 1.5 mT.

The dashed line represents the theoretical WHH model with Tc0 = 1.14 K and µ0dHc2/dT = −9.83 mT K−1 while the dashed–dotted line is a guide to the eye.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the The theoretical µ0Hc(T) values have been obtained by integrating the difference of speciﬁc heats between the superconducting (s) and normal (n) state and integrating the difference of the speciﬁc heats divided by temperature according to the formulas: −1 2µ0VMH2 c(T) = 1F(T) = 1U(T) −T1S(T) (3a) 1U(T) = Z Tc T [Cs(T′) −Cn(T′)]d(T′) (3b) 1S(T) = Z Tc T [Cs(T′) −Cn(T′)] T′ d(T′), (3c) where 1U(T) is the internal energy difference and 1S(T) is the entropy difference. Using the relation µ0VH2 c(0) = (3γn/2π2k2 B)(10/kB)2, the values γn = 5.2 × 10−3 J mol−1 K−2, VM = 68.24 × 10−6 m3 mol−1 and 10 = 1.51 K we obtained µ0Hc(0) = 5.76 mT at 0 K. This value is denoted by a solid diamond in ﬁgure 8(b).

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the A comparison of the calculated thermodynamic critical ﬁelds at 0 and 1.5 mT indicates that the temperature dependence of µ0Hc(T) is sensitive to applied magnetic ﬁelds. A remarkable ﬁnding of our measurements is that Tc(Hc2) = 0.85 K at zero ﬁeld attains its maximum value of 0.94 K in ﬁelds 1.5 and 2 mT.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the A comparison of the calculated thermodynamic critical ﬁelds at 0 and 1.5 mT indicates that the temperature dependence of µ0Hc(T) is sensitive to applied magnetic ﬁelds. A remarkable ﬁnding of our measurements is that Tc(Hc2) = 0.85 K at zero ﬁeld attains its maximum value of 0.94 K in ﬁelds 1.5 and 2 mT.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the Another aspect worth considering is the almost linear behavior of Hc2(Tc) above 2 mT. In fact, a ﬁt of the conventional relation Hc2(T) = Hc2(0)[1−(T/Tc(0))n] to the experimental data gives the critical ﬁeld Hc2(0) = 9.55 mT, critical temperature Tc(0) = 1.13 K and exponent n = 1.25.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the We calculated the upper critical ﬁeld using the model developed by Werthamer et al [20] (WHH model) for a type-II superconductor. Taking the slope of µ0Hc2(T) in the temperature range 0.63–0.94 K, dµ0Hc2(T)/dT = −9.83 mT K−1, and the orbital-limiting ﬁeld relation µ0Horb c2 = 0.73Tc(0)[−dµ0Hc2(T)/dT]Tc for a clean limit superconductor, we obtain µ0Horb c2 = 8.1 mT for Tc(0) = 1.13 K. It appears that all observed values of the critical ﬁelds are small and certainly indicate the absence of the Pauli limiting ﬁeld µ0Hp = 1.86Tc, which is of the order of ∼2 T. In order to support the dominant orbital-pair breaking effect we determined the value of the Maki parameter [20, 21], αM = (3e2¯hγVρ0)/(2π2k2 Bme) = 5.4 × 10−3.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the For µ0Hc c = 8.1 mT this results as ξab = 206 nm. Discussion and conclusions The ﬁrst picture which emerges from our measurements on single crystals of β-IrSn4 is that this binary intermetallic compound becomes superconducting below 0.9 ± 0.05 K. The zero-ﬁeld data listed in table 1 are in accordance with the conventional s-wave singlet pairing mechanism and would also provide a hint of either the type-I or type-II/1 superconductivity with a weak electron–phonon coupling.

Tc (K) 0.9 ± 0.05 µ0Hc0(0) (mT) 5.8 ± 0.1 αM 5.3 × 10−3 ¯λe–ph 0.5 ± 0.05 γn (mJ mol−1 K−2) 5.2 ± 0.2 β (mJ mol−1 K−4) 0.91 ± 0.15 1Cp/γnTc 1.3 ± 0.1 210/kBTc 3.55 ± 0.05 kF (×109 m−1) 4.7 ± 0.5 m∗(me) 3.1 ± 0.3 Fermi surface is expected.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the Thus, we are dealing with the fact that both RKW and the effective mass of ∼3 me are enhanced in β-IrSn4. Finally, an interesting outcome is obtained from comparison of the studied compound with the intermetallic compound AuSn4, which was previously reported to undergo a superconducting transition at Tc = 2.4 K [26, 27].

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the To summarize, we have grown single crystals of inter- metallic compound β-IrSn4, crystallizing in the tetragonal MoSn4-type structure. We found a superconducting transition Tc(0T) = 0.9 ± 0.05 K and an upper critical magnetic ﬁeld µ0Hc2(0) ∼8 mT.

Structural and electrical properties under high pressure for the superconducting spin-ladder system Sr0.4Ca13.6Cu24O411d M. Isobe, T. Ohta, M. Onoda, F. Izumi, S. Nakano, J. Q. Li,* Y. Matsui, and E. Takayama-Muromachi National Institute for Research in Inorganic Materials (NIRIM), 1-1 Namiki, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305 Japan T. Matsumoto We studied structural and electrical properties under high pressure and low temperature for a S51/2 Heisen- berg two-leg ladder compound Sr0.4Ca13.6Cu24O411d. It showed a superconducting transition above 3 GPa with a maximum Tc of 13 K. The Sr0.4Ca13.6Cu24O411d phase survives at least up to 9 GPa and down to 7 K without decomposition or phase transition, indicating that it is responsible for the observed superconductivity.

Important exceptions from this straightforward pic- ture were however found, and the best known one is YBa2Cu3O7 (Y-123) which is a 90-K superconductor, but possesses a metallic out-of-plane conductivity [7].

Kozeeva In the RBa2Cu3O61x system, superconductivity mostly hides the low-T region and the normal-state resistiv- ity can be measured down to fairly low temperatures only in a narrow doping range in the vicinity of the antiferromagnetic-superconducting (AFM-SC) phase boundary. For the sample with x ø 0.41, rc monotonically decreases within a wide temperature range from 127 K down to Tc ø 19 K. A tendency of rc to saturate is apparent for x ø 0.49 as well, but for such and higher doping levels the rc crossover is masked, because Tm quickly decreases with doping, while superconductivity in its turn hides the larger temperature range.

VOLUME 81, NUMBER 25 P H Y S I C A L R E V I E W L E T T E R S 21 DECEMBER 1998 Normal-State Resistivity Anisotropy in Underdoped RBa2Cu3O61x Crystals A. N. Lavrov,* M. Yu. Kameneva, and L. P. Kozeeva For comparison, in the right inset we show the anisotropy data obtained for a highly homogeneous platelike Lu-123 crystal. The same anisotropy saturation is obviously char- acteristic of SC samples as well, since rcsTd curves for crystals with Tc ø 19 K and TN ø 65 K, Figs.

VOLUME 81, NUMBER 25 P H Y S I C A L R E V I E W L E T T E R S 21 DECEMBER 1998 Normal-State Resistivity Anisotropy in Underdoped RBa2Cu3O61x Crystals A. N. Lavrov,* M. Yu. Kameneva, and L. P. Kozeeva However, we probably should search for a more general explanation for the puzzling c transport rather than that based on structural peculiarities of R-123. Actually, apart from the resistivity scale, similar behavior (rab ~ T2 and a crossover in rc at ø120 K) was observed in the noncuprate layered system Sr2RuO4 [15], and the anisotropy saturation at low T was reported for La22xSrxCuO4 [3].

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER Rietveld reﬁnement of powder XRD data conﬁrms that Re24Ti5 crystallizes in the α-Mn structure. All measured quantities demonstrate a bulk superconducting transition at Tc = 5.8 K. Our low-temperature speciﬁc heat data measured down to 0.5 K yield a Sommerfeld coefﬁcient γ = 111.8 mJ mol−1 K−2, which implies a high density of states at the Fermi level.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER In this respect, Re24Ti5 would provide an opportunity to search for the existence of a mixture of spin singlet and spin triplet states in the SC phase of the noncentrosymmetric compounds. In this paper, we report on the synthesis and charac- terization of Re24Ti5, which exhibits a distinct bulk SC transition at Tc ≃5.8 K. Measurements of the magnetic, transport, and thermal properties have been performed.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility for Re24Ti5 is shown in ﬁgure 2. The observed diamagnetic behavior below the transition temperature Tc ≃ 5.8 K conﬁrms the occurrence of superconductivity in this material.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER (2) Here µ∗is the Coulomb pseudopotential of about 0.13 used in Re23.8Nb5.2 and other intermetallic superconductors [9, 27, 28]. Taking θD = 428 K and Tc = 5.8 K, we obtained λep = 0.6 for Re24Ti5.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER The ﬁtting result is quite satisfactory, yielding an isotropic gap 1/kB of about 10.6 K for Re24Ti5. Also the superconducting transition temperature of 5.74 K revealed from the ﬁt is close to those from the transport and magnetic measurements.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER According to our Ce(T) analysis, Re24Ti5 is better described as an ordinary s-wave superconductor, indicating that a mixture of the spin singlet and triplet states in the SC phase driven by the ASOC effect is invisible. This result is likely due to a small band splitting lifted by ASOC as compared to the transition temperature Tc ≃5.8 K for Re24Ti5.

A standard analysis at 20 kOe yields a Sommerfeld constant n ¼ 43:7 mJ/(K2 mol), and a Debye temperature D ¼ 640 K calculated from ¼ Nð12=5Þ 4R3 D , where R ¼ 8:314 J/(K mol), N ¼ 20, and ¼ 0:147 mJ/(K4 mol).

High-pressure synchrotron-diffraction study of the superconducting spin-ladder compounds „Sr, M…14Cu24O41 „M5Ca, Ba, Nd… Ste´phanie Pachot and Pierre Bordet Laboratoire de Cristallographie CNRS, Boıˆte Postale 166, 38042 Grenoble Cedex 9, France Robert J. Cava Superconductivity was detected in a compound containing spin ladders by Uehara et al.,4 who measured the resistivity as a function of pressure and temperature in the (Sr142x ,Cax)Cu24O41 compounds. These authors reported the appearance of a superconducting transition in the 3–5 GPa range, with a maximum transition temperature of about 12 K, in samples with a large calcium concentration (x 513.6).

High-pressure synchrotron-diffraction study of the superconducting spin-ladder compounds „Sr, M…14Cu24O41 „M5Ca, Ba, Nd… Ste´phanie Pachot and Pierre Bordet Laboratoire de Cristallographie CNRS, Boıˆte Postale 166, 38042 Grenoble Cedex 9, France Robert J. Cava Since the superconducting properties of the (Sr142x ,Cax)Cu24O41 compound appear only at high pressure and for speciﬁc cal- cium concentrations, it is of the highest relevance to investi- gate the evolution of the structure with pressure and compo- sition. Therefore, we have carried out a high-pressure synchrotron-diffraction experiment at room temperature in the 0–10 GPa range for a set of (Sr142x ,M x)Cu24O41 samples with M5Ca, Ba, Nd, and x between 0 and 13.6 in order to investigate the combined effects of applied pressure, and modiﬁcation of the average ionic size and/or valence of the ~Sr, M!

Superconductor Science and Technology Isotropic superconductivity in LaRu2P2 with the Besides iron arsenide compounds, earlier works had already found other superconductors with the same crystal structure as BaFe2As2. Ruthenium phosphide LaRu2P2 was found to be superconducting at about 4 K more than 20 years ago [8].

Superconductor Science and Technology Isotropic superconductivity in LaRu2P2 with the This type of material has attracted much attention and showed a variety of interesting phenomena according to the composition of lanthanides and transition metals [11, 12]. Relatively high Tc for the other ruthenium phosphide superconductors were found in ZrRuP (Tc = 13 K) [13] and LaRu4P12 (Tc = 7.2 K) [14].

CONCLUSION We have presented measurements of the microwave surface impedance Z, (f, T,8) = R,(f, T,8) + i,ye~A'(f, T,B) for YBCO thin films at T = 4.3 K as a function of dc Geld B up to 5 T, microwave &equency 1.2 GHz & f & 20 GHz, and rf current in the range 10 A & I,g & 1 A.

PHYSICAL REVIEW B VOLUME 50, NUMBER 2 1 JULY 1994-II Frequency dependence field b = B/B,2, we identified the energy barriers for fiux motion to be generated by aux-line-lattice disorder, as explained by the collective-pinning theory. In order to be able to measure R, (f) at T) 70 K, the coupling of the resonator to the external circuit will be increased to improve the signal-to-noise ratio.

Tajima Superconductivity Research Laboratory, International Superconductivity Technology Center, 1-10-13 Shinonome, Koto-ku, Tokyo 135, Japan Single-crystal samples of YBa 2Cu 3O 6.92 prepared by a crystal-pulling technique12 are the same as were used in Ref. Anisotropic Hall mobility in slightly overdoped YBa2Cu3O6.92 from magnetoresistance and Hall-coefﬁcient measurements I. Terasaki, Y. Sato, and S. Tajima Superconductivity Research Laboratory, International Superconductivity Technology Center, 1-10-13 Shinonome, Koto-ku, Tokyo 135, Japan Because of the slightly overdoped nature, rab of our sample is about half of that in the optimally doped YBa 2Cu 3O y , and consequently the SF-induced MR DrSF;DsSF/sab 2 ;rab 2DsSF is ex- pected to be at most 25% of that in optimally doped crystals. In spite of this expectation, the observed MR above 100 K is as large as, or even slightly larger than, that in the optimally doped YBCO.

Anisotropic Hall mobility in slightly overdoped YBa2Cu3O6.92 from magnetoresistance and Hall-coefﬁcient measurements I. Terasaki, Y. Sato, and S. Tajima Superconductivity Research Laboratory, International Superconductivity Technology Center, 1-10-13 Shinonome, Koto-ku, Tokyo 135, Japan In spite of this expectation, the observed MR above 100 K is as large as, or even slightly larger than, that in the optimally doped YBCO. This strongly suggests that the MR above 100 K mainly comes from classical MR rather than SF.

Both ab-plane and c-axis thermal conductivities (kab and kc) of lightly doped La22xSrxCuO4 ~LSCO! and EXPERIMENTS The single crystals of LSCO and LCZO are grown by the traveling-solvent ﬂoating-zone technique, and carefully an- nealed in ﬂowing pure He gas to remove the excess oxygen.20 After the crystallographic axes are determined by using an x-ray Laue analysis, the crystals are cut into rectan- gular thin platelets with the typical sizes of 2.530.5 30.15 mm3, where the c axis is perpendicular or parallel to the platelet with an accuracy of 1°. The thermal conductivity k is measured in the temperature range of 2–300 K using a steady-state technique;21–23 above 150 K, a double thermal shielding is employed to minimize the heat loss due to radia- tion, and the residual radiation loss is corrected by using an elaborate measurement conﬁguration.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the Matter 25 (2013) 155701 (8pp) doi:10.1088/0953-8984/25/15/155701 Observation of superconductivity in the intermetallic compound β-IrSn4 Vinh Hung Tran, Zbigniew Bukowski, Piotr Wi´sniewski, Lan Maria Tran and Andrzej J Zaleski Institute of Low Temperature and Structure Research, Polish Academy of Sciences, PO Box 1410, 50-950 Wrocław, Poland E-mail: V.H.Tran@int.pan.wroc.pl Received 4 January 2013, in ﬁnal form 18 February 2013 Published 25 March 2013 Online at stacks.iop.org/JPhysCM/25/155701 Abstract Low-temperature dc-magnetization, ac electrical resistivity and speciﬁc heat measurements were performed on single crystals of the intermetallic compound β-IrSn4. The compound crystallizes in the tetragonal MoSn4-type structure (space group I41/acd) and exhibits superconductivity below Tc = 0.9 ± 0.05 K. Further, the magnitude of the ratios 1Cp/(γnkBTc) = 1.29, 21/(kBTc) = 3.55 and of the electron–phonon coupling λe−ph = 0.5 imply that superconductivity in β-IrSn4 can be ascribed to a s-wave weak coupling regime.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the Intermetallic IrSn4 binary crystallizes in three modiﬁca- tions; the low-temperature form, so-called α-IrSn4, adopts the trigonal IrGe4-type structure (space group P3121) [8], the high-temperature form, β-IrSn4 has the tetragonal MoSn4-type structure (space group I41/acd) [9], and the high-pressure form, HP-IrSn4, possesses the orthorhombic PtSn4-type structure (space group Ccca) [10, 11]. To the best of our knowledge, only α-IrSn4 was reported to be a Pauli paramagnet and non-superconducting down to 2 K [8], whereas none of physical properties of β-IrSn4 and HP-IrSn4 have been reported yet.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the The bottom panel is the powder x-ray diffraction pattern (small circle symbols) compared to a single crystal diffraction pattern (solid line) obtained using an x-ray beam perpendicular to the 00l plane. ducting with a transition temperature Tc of 0.9 ± 0.05 K. Although the zero-ﬁeld data characterize β-IrSn4 well as a s-wave weakly coupled type-I superconductor in a dirty limit, from an estimation of some thermodynamic parameters we arrive at a conclusion that superconductivity in β-IrSn4 can be ascribed to a type-II superconductor in a clean limit with an assumption of a non-spherical Fermi surface.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the Another aspect worth considering is the almost linear behavior of Hc2(Tc) above 2 mT. Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the We calculated the upper critical ﬁeld using the model developed by Werthamer et al [20] (WHH model) for a type-II superconductor. Taking the slope of µ0Hc2(T) in the temperature range 0.63–0.94 K, dµ0Hc2(T)/dT = −9.83 mT K−1, and the orbital-limiting ﬁeld relation µ0Horb c2 = 0.73Tc(0)[−dµ0Hc2(T)/dT]Tc for a clean limit superconductor, we obtain µ0Horb c2 = 8.1 mT for Tc(0) = 1.13 K. It appears that all observed values of the critical ﬁelds are small and certainly indicate the absence of the Pauli limiting ﬁeld µ0Hp = 1.86Tc, which is of the order of ∼2 T. In order to support the dominant orbital-pair breaking effect we determined the value of the Maki parameter [20, 21], αM = (3e2¯hγVρ0)/(2π2k2 Bme) = 5.4 × 10−3.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the For µ0Hc c = 8.1 mT this results as ξab = 206 nm. Discussion and conclusions The ﬁrst picture which emerges from our measurements on single crystals of β-IrSn4 is that this binary intermetallic compound becomes superconducting below 0.9 ± 0.05 K. The zero-ﬁeld data listed in table 1 are in accordance with the conventional s-wave singlet pairing mechanism and would also provide a hint of either the type-I or type-II/1 superconductivity with a weak electron–phonon coupling.

Finally, an interesting outcome is obtained from comparison of the studied compound with the intermetallic compound AuSn4, which was previously reported to undergo a superconducting transition at Tc = 2.4 K [26, 27].

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the To summarize, we have grown single crystals of inter- metallic compound β-IrSn4, crystallizing in the tetragonal MoSn4-type structure. We found a superconducting transition Tc(0T) = 0.9 ± 0.05 K and an upper critical magnetic ﬁeld µ0Hc2(0) ∼8 mT.

The observation of a higher critical ﬁeld in the parallel ﬁeld conﬁguration is consistent with the anisotropy of the 2D superconductivity.

ARTICLES PUBLISHED ONLINE: 17 AUGUST 2015 | DOI: 10.1038/NMAT4374 Large-area high-quality 2D ultrathin Mo2C superconducting crystals Chuan Xu1†, Libin Wang2†, Zhibo Liu1, Long Chen1, Jingkun Guo2, Ning Kang2*, Xiu-Liang Ma1, This value is much smaller than ξGL(0), which is consistent with the 2D behaviour of the superconductivity. 3d, we show a plot of Hc2 as a function of θ at 1.9 K, which exhibits a sharp cusp at the maximum when the magnetic field is applied parallel to the crystal plane.

ARTICLES PUBLISHED ONLINE: 17 AUGUST 2015 | DOI: 10.1038/NMAT4374 Large-area high-quality 2D ultrathin Mo2C superconducting crystals Chuan Xu1†, Libin Wang2†, Zhibo Liu1, Long Chen1, Jingkun Guo2, Ning Kang2*, Xiu-Liang Ma1, To further understand the superconductivity in ultrathin α-Mo2C crystals, we carried out current–voltage (I–V) measure- ments in the superconducting transition region. Figure 4a shows I–V curves taken at temperatures ranging from 1.8 to 3.1 K on a log–log scale.

ARTICLES PUBLISHED ONLINE: 17 AUGUST 2015 | DOI: 10.1038/NMAT4374 Large-area high-quality 2D ultrathin Mo2C superconducting crystals Chuan Xu1†, Libin Wang2†, Zhibo Liu1, Long Chen1, Jingkun Guo2, Ning Kang2*, Xiu-Liang Ma1, Figure 4b shows the temperature dependence of the exponent α. ARTICLES PUBLISHED ONLINE: 17 AUGUST 2015 | DOI: 10.1038/NMAT4374 Large-area high-quality 2D ultrathin Mo2C superconducting crystals Chuan Xu1†, Libin Wang2†, Zhibo Liu1, Long Chen1, Jingkun Guo2, Ning Kang2*, Xiu-Liang Ma1, They were then placed in a quartz tube of outer diameter 25 mm and inner diameter 22 mm to act as the growth substrates for ultrathin α-Mo2C crystals. Subsequently, the Cu/Mo bilayer substrates were heated above 1,085 ◦C in a horizontal tube furnace (Lindberg Blue M, TF55030C) under H2 (200 sccm).

ARTICLES PUBLISHED ONLINE: 17 AUGUST 2015 | DOI: 10.1038/NMAT4374 Large-area high-quality 2D ultrathin Mo2C superconducting crystals Chuan Xu1†, Libin Wang2†, Zhibo Liu1, Long Chen1, Jingkun Guo2, Ning Kang2*, Xiu-Liang Ma1, A thin layer of poly (methyl methacrylate) (PMMA, weight-averaged molecular mass Mw =600,000, 4 wt% in ethyl lactate) was first spin-coated on the surface of ultrathin α-Mo2C crystals at 5,000 r.p.m. for 1 min and cured at 180 ◦C for 30 min; the PMMA-coated samples were then immersed in a 0.2 M (NH4)2S2O8 solution at 70 ◦C for 10 min to etch the Cu substrate.

ARTICLES PUBLISHED ONLINE: 17 AUGUST 2015 | DOI: 10.1038/NMAT4374 Large-area high-quality 2D ultrathin Mo2C superconducting crystals Chuan Xu1†, Libin Wang2†, Zhibo Liu1, Long Chen1, Jingkun Guo2, Ning Kang2*, Xiu-Liang Ma1, for 1 min and cured at 180 ◦C for 30 min; the PMMA-coated samples were then immersed in a 0.2 M (NH4)2S2O8 solution at 70 ◦C for 10 min to etch the Cu substrate. After that, the PMMA-coated ultrathin α-Mo2C crystals were stamped onto target substrates, such as SiO2/Si and TEM grids, and warm acetone (55 ◦C) was used to dissolve the PMMA layer and obtain clean ultrathin α-Mo2C crystals.

PHYSICAL REVIEW B VOLUME 52, NUMBER 9 1 SEPTEMBER 1995-I Oxygen isotope effect on the effective mass of carriers from magnetic measurements Since the T, values of the ' 0-containing samples have a minimum at n =x =0.110, any isotope- induced increase or decrease in the hole concentration at this composition will always raise T,. The muon-spin-relaxation experiments' have shown a universal linear relationship: T, ~ 1/A,,b(0) ~ n /I * for underdoped Ii-type cuprates, where A,,b(0) is the in-plane penetration depth at zero temperature and m* is the effective mass of carriers along a-b plane.

Structural and electrical properties under high pressure for the superconducting spin-ladder system Sr0.4Ca13.6Cu24O411d M. Isobe, T. Ohta, M. Onoda, F. Izumi, S. Nakano, J. Q. Li,* Y. Matsui, and E. Takayama-Muromachi National Institute for Research in Inorganic Materials (NIRIM), 1-1 Namiki, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305 Japan T. Matsumoto We studied structural and electrical properties under high pressure and low temperature for a S51/2 Heisen- berg two-leg ladder compound Sr0.4Ca13.6Cu24O411d. It showed a superconducting transition above 3 GPa with a maximum Tc of 13 K. The Sr0.4Ca13.6Cu24O411d phase survives at least up to 9 GPa and down to 7 K without decomposition or phase transition, indicating that it is responsible for the observed superconductivity.

Structural and electrical properties under high pressure for the superconducting spin-ladder system Sr0.4Ca13.6Cu24O411d M. Isobe, T. Ohta, M. Onoda, F. Izumi, S. Nakano, J. Q. Li,* Y. Matsui, and E. Takayama-Muromachi National Institute for Research in Inorganic Materials (NIRIM), 1-1 Namiki, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305 Japan T. Matsumoto However, Sr4Ca10Cu24O411d did not show superconductivity up to 8.5 GPa.61 As shown in Table I, both the a and c axis shrink in nearly the same percentage after the Ca substitution, whereas pressure induces, in the high-temperature region, more aniso- tropic intraplane shrinkage with a larger percentage along the c axis than along the a axis. Expecting direct observation of the Peierls transition, we carried out electron-diffraction measurements around 100 K, but no evidence for it was obtained.

Structural and electrical properties under high pressure for the superconducting spin-ladder system Sr0.4Ca13.6Cu24O411d M. Isobe, T. Ohta, M. Onoda, F. Izumi, S. Nakano, J. Q. Li,* Y. Matsui, and E. Takayama-Muromachi National Institute for Research in Inorganic Materials (NIRIM), 1-1 Namiki, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305 Japan T. Matsumoto Expecting direct observation of the Peierls transition, we carried out electron-diffraction measurements around 100 K, but no evidence for it was obtained. In the temperature de- pendence of the b axis, however, we found an anomalous behavior near 150 K where the b axis does not change smoothly as a function of temperature, which cannot be in- terpreted using the classical Gru¨neisen’s equation of state.62 If there is really a breaking point, it means an abrupt change of the thermal-expansion coefﬁcient and the presence of a second-order phase transition.

Structural and electrical properties under high pressure for the superconducting spin-ladder system Sr0.4Ca13.6Cu24O411d M. Isobe, T. Ohta, M. Onoda, F. Izumi, S. Nakano, J. Q. Li,* Y. Matsui, and E. Takayama-Muromachi National Institute for Research in Inorganic Materials (NIRIM), 1-1 Namiki, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305 Japan T. Matsumoto have proposed the normal Fermi-liquid state for the present system under high pressure where superconduc- tivity is realized.40 Our data at 5 GPa seems to, roughly speaking, obey the T-square law, as well. The approach to the T-linear dependence from the T-square-like one near 300 K may be explained in terms of antiferromagnetic spin scattering using Fermi-liquid theo- ries as well as that for 2D high-Tc cuprates.63–65 According to the self-consistent renormalization theory, the r(T) is pro- portional to ;xQ5pT2;T2/(T1T)5T/T1 ~xQ is a staggered susceptibility, T1 is a nuclear spin-lattice relaxation time!.

Structural and electrical properties under high pressure for the superconducting spin-ladder system Sr0.4Ca13.6Cu24O411d M. Isobe, T. Ohta, M. Onoda, F. Izumi, S. Nakano, J. Q. Li,* Y. Matsui, and E. Takayama-Muromachi National Institute for Research in Inorganic Materials (NIRIM), 1-1 Namiki, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305 Japan T. Matsumoto The approach to the T-linear dependence from the T-square-like one near 300 K may be explained in terms of antiferromagnetic spin scattering using Fermi-liquid theo- ries as well as that for 2D high-Tc cuprates.63–65 According to the self-consistent renormalization theory, the r(T) is pro- portional to ;xQ5pT2;T2/(T1T)5T/T1 ~xQ is a staggered susceptibility, T1 is a nuclear spin-lattice relaxation time!. Since T1 approaches to be constant with increasing temperature,66 r(T) is proportional to T at the high- temperature limit.

Structural and electrical properties under high pressure for the superconducting spin-ladder system Sr0.4Ca13.6Cu24O411d M. Isobe, T. Ohta, M. Onoda, F. Izumi, S. Nakano, J. Q. Li,* Y. Matsui, and E. Takayama-Muromachi National Institute for Research in Inorganic Materials (NIRIM), 1-1 Namiki, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305 Japan T. Matsumoto V. CONCLUSIONS We studied the x-ray diffraction and electrical resistivity in a composite crystal Sr0.4Ca13.6Cu24O411d under high pres- sure and low temperature to discuss the nature of the elec- tronic state and pressure-induced superconductivity from crystallographic aspects. The Sr0.4Ca13.6Cu24O411d phase sur- vives at least for P<9 GPa and T>7 K indicating that it is responsible for superconductivity observed only under high pressure.

Structural and electrical properties under high pressure for the superconducting spin-ladder system Sr0.4Ca13.6Cu24O411d M. Isobe, T. Ohta, M. Onoda, F. Izumi, S. Nakano, J. Q. Li,* Y. Matsui, and E. Takayama-Muromachi National Institute for Research in Inorganic Materials (NIRIM), 1-1 Namiki, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305 Japan T. Matsumoto Holes are doped into ladders from 1D chains via lo- cally formed Culadder 3d and Ochain 2p hybrid orbitals. The r-T curves in the normal state above 5 GPa obey a power law of tem- perature in the wide range of temperature between 7 and over 200 K, suggesting that carriers are mainly scattered by spin ﬂuctuation as well as in 2D high-Tc cuprates.

VOLUME 81, NUMBER 25 P H Y S I C A L R E V I E W L E T T E R S 21 DECEMBER 1998 Normal-State Resistivity Anisotropy in Underdoped RBa2Cu3O61x Crystals A. N. Lavrov,* M. Yu. Kameneva, and L. P. Kozeeva In the RBa2Cu3O61x system, superconductivity mostly hides the low-T region and the normal-state resistiv- ity can be measured down to fairly low temperatures only in a narrow doping range in the vicinity of the antiferromagnetic-superconducting (AFM-SC) phase boundary. For the sample with x ø 0.41, rc monotonically decreases within a wide temperature range from 127 K down to Tc ø 19 K. A tendency of rc to saturate is apparent for x ø 0.49 as well, but for such and higher doping levels the rc crossover is masked, because Tm quickly decreases with doping, while superconductivity in its turn hides the larger temperature range.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER Rietveld reﬁnement of powder XRD data conﬁrms that Re24Ti5 crystallizes in the α-Mn structure. All measured quantities demonstrate a bulk superconducting transition at Tc = 5.8 K. Our low-temperature speciﬁc heat data measured down to 0.5 K yield a Sommerfeld coefﬁcient γ = 111.8 mJ mol−1 K−2, which implies a high density of states at the Fermi level.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER Rietveld reﬁnement of powder XRD data conﬁrms that Re24Ti5 crystallizes in the α-Mn structure. All measured quantities demonstrate a bulk superconducting transition at Tc = 5.8 K. Our low-temperature speciﬁc heat data measured down to 0.5 K yield a Sommerfeld coefﬁcient γ = 111.8 mJ mol−1 K−2, which implies a high density of states at the Fermi level.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER All measured quantities demonstrate a bulk superconducting transition at Tc = 5.8 K. Our low-temperature speciﬁc heat data measured down to 0.5 K yield a Sommerfeld coefﬁcient γ = 111.8 mJ mol−1 K−2, which implies a high density of states at the Fermi level. Moreover, the electronic speciﬁc heat in the superconducting state was found to obey a typical s-wave expression, revealing a single gap 1/kB = 10.6 K. This value gives a ratio of 21/kBTc = 3.68, higher than the value of 3.5 predicted from BCS theory.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER In this respect, Re24Ti5 would provide an opportunity to search for the existence of a mixture of spin singlet and spin triplet states in the SC phase of the noncentrosymmetric compounds. In this paper, we report on the synthesis and charac- terization of Re24Ti5, which exhibits a distinct bulk SC transition at Tc ≃5.8 K. Measurements of the magnetic, transport, and thermal properties have been performed.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER Experimental results and discussion A nominally stoichiometric Re24Ti5 sample was prepared from 99.997% Re and 99.95% Ti by mixing appropriate amounts of elemental metals. The resulting ingot was annealed in a vacuum-sealed quartz tube at 800 ◦C for ﬁve days, followed by furnace cooling.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER A room-temperature x-ray diffraction analysis taken with Cu Kα radiation on the powdered sample Figure 2. Temperature dependence of magnetic susceptibility under zero-ﬁeld-cooled (ZFC) and ﬁeld-cooled (FC) processes for Re24Ti5 measured at Ho = 10 Oe.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility for Re24Ti5 is shown in ﬁgure 2. The observed diamagnetic behavior below the transition temperature Tc ≃ 5.8 K conﬁrms the occurrence of superconductivity in this material.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER Here Tc was deﬁned as the onset of the diamagnetic response in the magnetization data, as indicated by the arrow in ﬁgure 2. Neglecting the details of the demagnetization effect, the value of 4πχ (ZFC) at 2 K exceeding −1 indicates that the shielding volume fraction is almost 100%.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER The observed temperature dependence of the electrical resistivity for Re24Ti5 is displayed in ﬁgure 3. The normal state resistivity between 6.5 and 14 K can be described well by a power law ρ(T) = ρo + AT2, (1) where ρo is the residual resistivity and A is the temperature coefﬁcient of the electric resistivity.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER Electrical resistivity as a function of temperature for Re24Ti5. Inset: a plot of ρ versus T2, showing a linear relation between 6.5 and 14 K. yielding ρo = 214.8 µ cm and A = 0.022 µ cm K−2.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER Electrical resistivity as a function of temperature for Re24Ti5. Inset: a plot of ρ versus T2, showing a linear relation between 6.5 and 14 K. yielding ρo = 214.8 µ cm and A = 0.022 µ cm K−2.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER It is instructive to mention that the electron–electron scattering rate at low temperatures should grow as T2 in the Fermi liquid picture while the residual resistivity ρo may arise from electron scattering due to domain boundaries and/or defects. The value of ρo provides an estimate of the residual resistivity ratio (RRR, ρ (300 K)/ρo) of about 1.3 for Re24Ti5.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER No anomalous feature at or below Tc can be detected to the lowest measured temperature, indicating that the heat transport is insensitive to the electron condensation in Re24Ti5. However, κ(T) shows a clear shoulder near 50 K, commonly seen in solids at low temperatures due to phonon processes.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER The superconducting transition of Re24Ti5 manifests itself by the abrupt drop in S, as indicated in the inset of ﬁgure 5. The Seebeck coefﬁcient develops a broad minimum at around 70 K which is ascribed to the phonon-drag effect.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER The Seebeck coefﬁcient develops a broad minimum at around 70 K which is ascribed to the phonon-drag effect. Between 150 and 300 K, the observed S varies rather linearly with T, indicating that the diffusion thermopower Sd plays an important role within this temperature range.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER The Seebeck coefﬁcient develops a broad minimum at around 70 K which is ascribed to the phonon-drag effect. Between 150 and 300 K, the observed S varies rather linearly with T, indicating that the diffusion thermopower Sd plays an important role within this temperature range.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER Such an argument was based on the classical formula |Sd| = π2k2 BT/2eEF, assuming a one-band model with an energy-independent relaxation time [21]. From the slope of 0.019 µV K−2, we can extract the magnitude of Fermi energy EF = 1.93 eV (corresponding to the Fermi temperature TF = 22 400 K).

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER Also the linear temperature dependence of Sd was thus evaluated, shown as a solid straight line in ﬁgure 5. In addition to Sd, the remaining part (the dotted curve in ﬁgure 5) arising from the phonon-drag effect, termed as Sg, can be obtained by subtracting Sd from the observed S. The low-temperature speciﬁc heat C measurements were performed using a 3He heat-pulsed thermal relaxation calorimeter in the temperature range from 0.5 to 10 K with the application of a magnetic ﬁeld up to 8 T. The zero-ﬁeld and 5 T speciﬁc heat data of Re24Ti5 are shown in ﬁgure 6.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER We thus employed the BCS formula for Ce(T) to ﬁt the result of Ce/T with the ﬁtting curve also displayed in ﬁgure 9. The ﬁtting result is quite satisfactory, yielding an isotropic gap 1/kB of about 10.6 K for Re24Ti5.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER The ﬁtting result is quite satisfactory, yielding an isotropic gap 1/kB of about 10.6 K for Re24Ti5. Also the superconducting transition temperature of 5.74 K revealed from the ﬁt is close to those from the transport and magnetic measurements.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER The ﬁtting result is quite satisfactory, yielding an isotropic gap 1/kB of about 10.6 K for Re24Ti5. Also the superconducting transition temperature of 5.74 K revealed from the ﬁt is close to those from the transport and magnetic measurements.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER According to our Ce(T) analysis, Re24Ti5 is better described as an ordinary s-wave superconductor, indicating that a mixture of the spin singlet and triplet states in the SC phase driven by the ASOC effect is invisible. This result is likely due to a small band splitting lifted by ASOC as compared to the transition temperature Tc ≃5.8 K for Re24Ti5.

For measuring the Seebeck effect the ap- plied temperature gradient was kept as small as possible in order to minimize the temperature difference between the two voltage leads. definition: Superconducting State of the Binary Boride Ru7B3 with the Noncentrosymmetric Crystal Structure Naoki KASE and Jun AKIMITSU Department of Physics and Mathematics, Aoyama Gakuin University, 5-10-1 Fuchinobe, Sagamihara, Kanagawa 229-8558 We calculated the GL coherence length GL and magnetic penetration depth GL, with the formulae Hc2 ¼ 0=2 2 GL, where 0 is the ﬂux quantum, and Hc1 ¼ 0= 2 GL. The coherence length ð0ÞGL and the penetration depth ð0ÞGL obtained using these formulae were estimated to be 144 and 3110 A˚ for H k ½100, and 138 and 3520 A˚ for H k ½001, respectively.

definition: Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the The London penetration depth λL(0) = 162 nm can be obtained from the formula: λL(0) = q m∗c2 4πnse2 , where c is the speed of light. On the other hand, using the BCS relation for the coherence length ξ0 = 0.18¯hυF/kBTc, we obtained ξ0 = 261 nm, where υF = ¯hkF/m∗= 1.71×105 m s−1 is the Fermi velocity.

definition: PHYSICAL REVIEW B VOLUME 50, NUMBER 5 1 AUGUST 1994-I Nernst, Seebeck, and Hall efFects in the mixed state of YBazCu3O'7 —$ and Bi2Sr2CaCuzOs+ For the magnetic field applied parallel to the c axis of the films, approximately the same value of the transport entropy was found for YBazCu307 g and BizSrzCaCuzO, +, showing that the different anisotropy of these materials has little influence on this quantity. ARTICLES PUBLISHED ONLINE: 17 AUGUST 2015 | DOI: 10.1038/NMAT4374 Large-area high-quality 2D ultrathin Mo2C superconducting crystals Chuan Xu1†, Libin Wang2†, Zhibo Liu1, Long Chen1, Jingkun Guo2, Ning Kang2*, Xiu-Liang Ma1, Importantly, the CVD growth method developed is versatile, and can be used as a general strategy for fabricating a broad class of high- quality 2D ultrathin TMC crystals. For example, high-quality ultra- thin WC and TaC crystals, which were also stable under ambient conditions, were fabricated using W or Ta foils to replace the Mo foils during the growth process (Supplementary Figs 18 and 19).

Superconducting State of the Binary Boride Ru7B3 with the Noncentrosymmetric Crystal Structure Naoki KASE and Jun AKIMITSU Department of Physics and Mathematics, Aoyama Gakuin University, 5-10-1 Fuchinobe, Sagamihara, Kanagawa 229-8558 In conclusion, we reveal the physical properties in detail of the binary type-II superconductor, Ru7B3 by means of magnetic susceptibility ðTÞ, electrical resistivity ðTÞ, and magnetization MðHÞ measurements. Ru7B3 crystallizes in a hexagonal structure with a space group of P63mc.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the Matter 25 (2013) 155701 (8pp) doi:10.1088/0953-8984/25/15/155701 Observation of superconductivity in the intermetallic compound β-IrSn4 Vinh Hung Tran, Zbigniew Bukowski, Piotr Wi´sniewski, Lan Maria Tran and Andrzej J Zaleski Institute of Low Temperature and Structure Research, Polish Academy of Sciences, PO Box 1410, 50-950 Wrocław, Poland E-mail: V.H.Tran@int.pan.wroc.pl Received 4 January 2013, in ﬁnal form 18 February 2013 Published 25 March 2013 Online at stacks.iop.org/JPhysCM/25/155701 Abstract Low-temperature dc-magnetization, ac electrical resistivity and speciﬁc heat measurements were performed on single crystals of the intermetallic compound β-IrSn4. The compound crystallizes in the tetragonal MoSn4-type structure (space group I41/acd) and exhibits superconductivity below Tc = 0.9 ± 0.05 K. Further, the magnitude of the ratios 1Cp/(γnkBTc) = 1.29, 21/(kBTc) = 3.55 and of the electron–phonon coupling λe−ph = 0.5 imply that superconductivity in β-IrSn4 can be ascribed to a s-wave weak coupling regime.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the These discoveries have not only broken the exclusive association between type-I superconductivity and elemental metals, but have encouraged further investigation of type-I superconductivity, since a ﬁeld-dependent anisotropic order parameter in the superconducting state has been considered for LaRhSi3 [7]. Intermetallic IrSn4 binary crystallizes in three modiﬁca- tions; the low-temperature form, so-called α-IrSn4, adopts the trigonal IrGe4-type structure (space group P3121) [8], the high-temperature form, β-IrSn4 has the tetragonal MoSn4-type structure (space group I41/acd) [9], and the high-pressure form, HP-IrSn4, possesses the orthorhombic PtSn4-type structure (space group Ccca) [10, 11].

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER 26 (2013) 055011 C S Lue et al Figure 1. Rietveld reﬁnement of the powder x-ray diffraction data from Re24Ti5 shows the main I¯43m phase with a minor impurity peak arising from TiO2 marked by the asterisk.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER It is seen that the diffraction spectrum in this material is identical to the expected structure, with a minor impurity peak arising from TiO2 which has little effect on the superconducting nature of Re24Ti5. In a more detailed analysis of the x-ray data, the I¯43m phase was reﬁned with the Rietveld method.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER The value of ρo provides an estimate of the residual resistivity ratio (RRR, ρ (300 K)/ρo) of about 1.3 for Re24Ti5. This result is similar to those of the α-Mn-type compounds Re3W (RRR ∼1.1) and Re23.8Nb5.2 (RRR ∼1.3) [8, 9], suggesting that the small RRR is a common feature for the Re-based superconductors with the noncentrosymmetric α-Mn crystal structure.

Cava Since the superconducting properties of the (Sr142x ,Cax)Cu24O41 compound appear only at high pressure and for speciﬁc cal- cium concentrations, it is of the highest relevance to investi- gate the evolution of the structure with pressure and compo- sition. Science and Technology of Advanced Materials ISSN: 1468-6996 (Print) 1878-5514 (Online) Journal homepage: www.tandfonline.com/journals/tsta20 Data-driven exploration of new pressure-induced superconductivity in PbBi2Te4 Ryo Matsumoto, Zhufeng Hou, Masanori Nagao, Shintaro Adachi, Hiroshi We focused on PbBi2Te4 which has the similar electronic band structure and the same crystal structure with those of a pressure-induced superconductor SnBi2Se4 explored by the same data-driven approach. EXPERIMENTS The single crystals of LSCO and LCZO are grown by the traveling-solvent ﬂoating-zone technique, and carefully an- nealed in ﬂowing pure He gas to remove the excess oxygen.20 After the crystallographic axes are determined by using an x-ray Laue analysis, the crystals are cut into rectan- gular thin platelets with the typical sizes of 2.530.5 30.15 mm3, where the c axis is perpendicular or parallel to the platelet with an accuracy of 1°.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the In this ﬁgure we compare also the temperature dependences of the thermodynamic critical ﬁelds µ0Hc(T) calculated from the Cp-data at 0 and 1.5 mT. The theoretical µ0Hc(T) values have been obtained by integrating the difference of speciﬁc heats between the superconducting (s) and normal (n) state and integrating the difference of the speciﬁc heats divided by temperature according to the formulas: −1 2µ0VMH2 c(T) = 1F(T) = 1U(T) −T1S(T) (3a) 1U(T) = Z Tc T [Cs(T′) −Cn(T′)]d(T′) (3b) 1S(T) = Z Tc T [Cs(T′) −Cn(T′)] T′ d(T′), (3c) where 1U(T) is the internal energy difference and 1S(T) is the entropy difference.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the Another aspect worth considering is the almost linear behavior of Hc2(Tc) above 2 mT. In fact, a ﬁt of the conventional relation Hc2(T) = Hc2(0)[1−(T/Tc(0))n] to the experimental data gives the critical ﬁeld Hc2(0) = 9.55 mT, critical temperature Tc(0) = 1.13 K and exponent n = 1.25.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the We calculated the upper critical ﬁeld using the model developed by Werthamer et al [20] (WHH model) for a type-II superconductor. Taking the slope of µ0Hc2(T) in the temperature range 0.63–0.94 K, dµ0Hc2(T)/dT = −9.83 mT K−1, and the orbital-limiting ﬁeld relation µ0Horb c2 = 0.73Tc(0)[−dµ0Hc2(T)/dT]Tc for a clean limit superconductor, we obtain µ0Horb c2 = 8.1 mT for Tc(0) = 1.13 K. It appears that all observed values of the critical ﬁelds are small and certainly indicate the absence of the Pauli limiting ﬁeld µ0Hp = 1.86Tc, which is of the order of ∼2 T. In order to support the dominant orbital-pair breaking effect we determined the value of the Maki parameter [20, 21], αM = (3e2¯hγVρ0)/(2π2k2 Bme) = 5.4 × 10−3.

The measured data exhibit a power-law dependence, V ∝I α, becoming increasingly nonlinear with decreasing tempera- ture, consistent with expectations for a 2D superconductor based on the theoretical model of the Berezinskii–Kosterlitz–Thouless (BKT) transition20,21.

ARTICLES PUBLISHED ONLINE: 17 AUGUST 2015 | DOI: 10.1038/NMAT4374 Large-area high-quality 2D ultrathin Mo2C superconducting crystals Chuan Xu1†, Libin Wang2†, Zhibo Liu1, Long Chen1, Jingkun Guo2, Ning Kang2*, Xiu-Liang Ma1, Below Tc, α(T) increases from unity, growing rapidly below 2.8 K. We identify the temperature T = 2.86 K at which the exponent α reaches a value of 3 as the BKT transition temperature TBKT. At temperatures just above TBKT, R(T) can be predicted using the following equation22–24 R=R0 exp(−bt −1/2) (1) where R0 and b are material-specific parameters and t =T/TBKT −1 is the reduced temperature.

Matsumoto suggested by bond- valence-sum calculations that holes are almost completely located at the 1D chain sites in Sr14Cu24O411d and they move into ladder sites with increasing the Ca content.38 After the Ca substitution, Osafune et al. Based on this result they proposed the charge redistribution from the 1D chain site to the ladder one.53 From Madelung potential calculations, Mizumo and co-workers have also concluded that holes are located on the 1D chain in the Sr-based phase and Ca substitution makes them move to the ladder.54,55 The ladder subsystem is more conductive than the 1D chain along the c axis since it has a larger transfer integral due to ;180° Cu-O-Cu bond com- pared with ;90° Cu-O-Cu bond in the 1D chain.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER 26 (2013) 055011 (6pp) doi:10.1088/0953-2048/26/5/055011 Investigation of normal and superconducting states in noncentrosymmetric Re24Ti5 C S Lue1, H F Liu1, C N Kuo1, P S Shih2, J-Y Lin2, Y K Kuo3, M W Chu4, T-L Hung5 and Y Y Chen5 1 Department of Physics, National Cheng Kung University, Tainan 70101, Taiwan 2 Institute of Physics, National Chiao Tung University, Hsinchu 30010, Taiwan 3 Department of Physics, National Dong Hwa University, Hualien 97401, Taiwan 4 Center for Condensed Matter Sciences, National Taiwan University, Taipei 10601, Taiwan 5 Institute of Physics, Academia Sinica, Taipei 11529, Taiwan E-mail: ago@cc.nctu.edu.tw (J-Y Lin) and ykkuo@mail.ndhu.edu.tw Received 19 December 2012, in ﬁnal form 27 February 2013 Published 4 April 2013 Online at stacks.iop.org/SUST/26/055011 Abstract We report a detailed characterization of the noncentrosymmetric superconductor Re24Ti5 using powder x-ray diffraction (XRD), magnetic susceptibility, electrical resistivity, thermal conductivity, Seebeck coefﬁcient, and speciﬁc heat measurements. Rietveld reﬁnement of powder XRD data conﬁrms that Re24Ti5 crystallizes in the α-Mn structure.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER 26 (2013) 055011 (6pp) doi:10.1088/0953-2048/26/5/055011 Investigation of normal and superconducting states in noncentrosymmetric Re24Ti5 C S Lue1, H F Liu1, C N Kuo1, P S Shih2, J-Y Lin2, Y K Kuo3, M W Chu4, T-L Hung5 and Y Y Chen5 1 Department of Physics, National Cheng Kung University, Tainan 70101, Taiwan 2 Institute of Physics, National Chiao Tung University, Hsinchu 30010, Taiwan 3 Department of Physics, National Dong Hwa University, Hualien 97401, Taiwan 4 Center for Condensed Matter Sciences, National Taiwan University, Taipei 10601, Taiwan 5 Institute of Physics, Academia Sinica, Taipei 11529, Taiwan E-mail: ago@cc.nctu.edu.tw (J-Y Lin) and ykkuo@mail.ndhu.edu.tw Received 19 December 2012, in ﬁnal form 27 February 2013 Published 4 April 2013 Online at stacks.iop.org/SUST/26/055011 Abstract We report a detailed characterization of the noncentrosymmetric superconductor Re24Ti5 using powder x-ray diffraction (XRD), magnetic susceptibility, electrical resistivity, thermal conductivity, Seebeck coefﬁcient, and speciﬁc heat measurements. Structural and electrical properties under high pressure for the superconducting spin-ladder system Sr0.4Ca13.6Cu24O411d M. Isobe, T. Ohta, M. Onoda, F. Izumi, S. Nakano, J. Q. Li,* Y. Matsui, and E. Takayama-Muromachi National Institute for Research in Inorganic Materials (NIRIM), 1-1 Namiki, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305 Japan T. Matsumoto We studied structural and electrical properties under high pressure and low temperature for a S51/2 Heisen- berg two-leg ladder compound Sr0.4Ca13.6Cu24O411d. It showed a superconducting transition above 3 GPa with a maximum Tc of 13 K. The Sr0.4Ca13.6Cu24O411d phase survives at least up to 9 GPa and down to 7 K without decomposition or phase transition, indicating that it is responsible for the observed superconductivity.

Structural and electrical properties under high pressure for the superconducting spin-ladder system Sr0.4Ca13.6Cu24O411d M. Isobe, T. Ohta, M. Onoda, F. Izumi, S. Nakano, J. Q. Li,* Y. Matsui, and E. Takayama-Muromachi National Institute for Research in Inorganic Materials (NIRIM), 1-1 Namiki, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305 Japan T. Matsumoto Though Sr14Cu241yO411d shows semiconducting behav- ior, resistivity decreases with Ca substitution for Sr.36–39 Re- cently, Uehara et al. succeeded in preparing a highly Ca- substituted phase Sr0.4Ca13.6Cu24O41.84 under high oxygen pressure and reported that it shows superconductivity with the maximum Tc of 12 K near 3 GPa.40 Their sensational report seems to prove the theoretical prediction on the spin- ladder system.

definition: Superconductor Science and Technology Isotropic superconductivity in LaRu2P2 with the Within the weak-coupling BCS theory, the upper critical ﬁeld at T = 0 K can be determined by the Werthamer–Helfand–Hohenberg (WHH) equation [17] Hc2(0) = 0.693[−(dHc2/dT )]TcTc. The value of Hc2(0) was estimated as about 1140 Oe, which is much smaller than that in iron-based superconductors.

property_name: Hc2 at given temperature for single crystal H//ab-plane
definition: Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the If β-IrSn4 is considered as a type-II superconductor then one can estimate the lower critical ﬁeld µ0Hc1 and the upper critical ﬁeld µ0Hc2. µ0Hc1 = 3 mT, if is deﬁned as the ﬁeld where the deviation of the M(H) curve from linearity in the Meissner state sets in, while µ0Hc2 = 6.5 mT at 0.5 K, determined as the intersection between linear interpolations of the magnetization in the superconducting and normal states.

property_name: Hc2 at given temperature for single crystal H//ab-plane
definition: Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the Upon increasing the magnetic ﬁelds, the superconducting transition shifts to lower temperatures and even a small ﬁeld of 10 mT is sufﬁcient to reduce the Tc to less than 0.5 K. From the ﬁeld dependence of the resistivity we have determined the upper critical ﬁeld. At 0.45 K µ0Hc2 = 6.8 mT (see ﬁgure 3(b)), which is in good agreement with the value obtained from the magnetization measurements.

Superconducting State of the Binary Boride Ru7B3 with the Noncentrosymmetric Crystal Structure Naoki KASE and Jun AKIMITSU Department of Physics and Mathematics, Aoyama Gakuin University, 5-10-1 Fuchinobe, Sagamihara, Kanagawa 229-8558  Superconducting State of the Binary Boride Ru7B3 with the Noncentrosymmetric Crystal Structure Naoki KASE and Jun AKIMITSU Department of Physics and Mathematics, Aoyama Gakuin University, 5-10-1 Fuchinobe, Sagamihara, Kanagawa 229-8558 (Received November 12, 2008; accepted January 14, 2009; published April 10, 2009) Single crystals of Ru7B3 were grown by the Czochralski puling method in a tetra-arc furnace.

Superconducting State of the Binary Boride Ru7B3 with the Noncentrosymmetric Crystal Structure Naoki KASE and Jun AKIMITSU Department of Physics and Mathematics, Aoyama Gakuin University, 5-10-1 Fuchinobe, Sagamihara, Kanagawa 229-8558 Ru7B3 was reported as a superconductor with Tc ¼ 2:58{3:38 K using a polycrystalline sample,10,11) de- spite the lack of report on its superconducting state. To investigate the superconducting state more precisely, we have succeeded in growing single crystals of Ru7B3 using the Czochralski pulling method.

Superconducting State of the Binary Boride Ru7B3 with the Noncentrosymmetric Crystal Structure Naoki KASE and Jun AKIMITSU Department of Physics and Mathematics, Aoyama Gakuin University, 5-10-1 Fuchinobe, Sagamihara, Kanagawa 229-8558 Ru7B3 was reported as a superconductor with Tc ¼ 2:58{3:38 K using a polycrystalline sample,10,11) de- spite the lack of report on its superconducting state. To investigate the superconducting state more precisely, we have succeeded in growing single crystals of Ru7B3 using the Czochralski pulling method.

Superconducting State of the Binary Boride Ru7B3 with the Noncentrosymmetric Crystal Structure Naoki KASE and Jun AKIMITSU Department of Physics and Mathematics, Aoyama Gakuin University, 5-10-1 Fuchinobe, Sagamihara, Kanagawa 229-8558 In this report, we reveal their superconducting and normal state properties on a pure single crystal of Ru7B3. The polycrystal ingots were prepared by an arc-melting method with a ﬁne Ru powder (99.9%) and an amorphous B powder (99.5%) with a nominal Ru/B ratio of 2.0, including an excess B powder in consideration of the low boron vapor pressure.

Superconducting State of the Binary Boride Ru7B3 with the Noncentrosymmetric Crystal Structure Naoki KASE and Jun AKIMITSU Department of Physics and Mathematics, Aoyama Gakuin University, 5-10-1 Fuchinobe, Sagamihara, Kanagawa 229-8558 The polycrystal ingots were prepared by an arc-melting method with a ﬁne Ru powder (99.9%) and an amorphous B powder (99.5%) with a nominal Ru/B ratio of 2.0, including an excess B powder in consideration of the low boron vapor pressure. The single crystals were grown by the Czochralski pulling method using the tetra-arc furnace in Ar atmosphere and growth rate was set to 10 mm/h.

Superconducting State of the Binary Boride Ru7B3 with the Noncentrosymmetric Crystal Structure Naoki KASE and Jun AKIMITSU Department of Physics and Mathematics, Aoyama Gakuin University, 5-10-1 Fuchinobe, Sagamihara, Kanagawa 229-8558 The polycrystal ingots were prepared by an arc-melting method with a ﬁne Ru powder (99.9%) and an amorphous B powder (99.5%) with a nominal Ru/B ratio of 2.0, including an excess B powder in consideration of the low boron vapor pressure. The single crystals were grown by the Czochralski pulling method using the tetra-arc furnace in Ar atmosphere and growth rate was set to 10 mm/h.

Superconducting State of the Binary Boride Ru7B3 with the Noncentrosymmetric Crystal Structure Naoki KASE and Jun AKIMITSU Department of Physics and Mathematics, Aoyama Gakuin University, 5-10-1 Fuchinobe, Sagamihara, Kanagawa 229-8558 It is inferred from these results that such a weak-coupling ratio and Fermi surface properties cannot be the source of Hc2 increase. We have prepared a nonstoichiometric polycrystalline specimen, which is used in the present experiments as a sample with a nominal Ru/B ratio of 2.0 corresponding to excess boron.

Superconducting State of the Binary Boride Ru7B3 with the Noncentrosymmetric Crystal Structure Naoki KASE and Jun AKIMITSU Department of Physics and Mathematics, Aoyama Gakuin University, 5-10-1 Fuchinobe, Sagamihara, Kanagawa 229-8558 The single crystal growth of Re7B3 is currently in progress. In conclusion, we reveal the physical properties in detail of the binary type-II superconductor, Ru7B3 by means of magnetic susceptibility ðTÞ, electrical resistivity ðTÞ, and magnetization MðHÞ measurements.

Science and Technology of Advanced Materials ISSN: 1468-6996 (Print) 1878-5514 (Online) Journal homepage: www.tandfonline.com/journals/tsta20 Data-driven exploration of new pressure-induced superconductivity in PbBi2Te4 Ryo Matsumoto, Zhufeng Hou, Masanori Nagao, Shintaro Adachi, Hiroshi We focused on PbBi2Te4 which has the similar electronic band structure and the same crystal structure with those of a pressure-induced superconductor SnBi2Se4 explored by the same data-driven approach. The PbBi2Te4 was successfully synthesized as single crystals using a melt and slow cooling method.

Sample synthesis Single crystals of PbBi2Te4 were grown by a melt and slow-cooling method.

Science and Technology of Advanced Materials ISSN: 1468-6996 (Print) 1878-5514 (Online) Journal homepage: www.tandfonline.com/journals/tsta20 Data-driven exploration of new pressure-induced superconductivity in PbBi2Te4 Ryo Matsumoto, Zhufeng Hou, Masanori Nagao, Shintaro Adachi, Hiroshi Starting materials of Pb grains, Bi grains, and Te chips were put into an evacuated quartz tube in the stoichiometric composition of PbBi2Te4. The ampoule was heated at 1000 °C for 1 h, and then slowly cooled down to 800 °C within 20 h in the furnace.

Science and Technology of Advanced Materials ISSN: 1468-6996 (Print) 1878-5514 (Online) Journal homepage: www.tandfonline.com/journals/tsta20 Data-driven exploration of new pressure-induced superconductivity in PbBi2Te4 Ryo Matsumoto, Zhufeng Hou, Masanori Nagao, Shintaro Adachi, Hiroshi The valence state was esti- mated by the core level XPS analysis using AXIS-ULTRA DLD (Shimadzu/Kratos) with monochromatic Al Kα X-ray radiation (hν = 1486.6 eV), operating under a pressure of the order of 10−9 Torr. The samples were cleaved using Scotch tape in a vacuum of approximately 10−7 Torr.

Science and Technology of Advanced Materials ISSN: 1468-6996 (Print) 1878-5514 (Online) Journal homepage: www.tandfonline.com/journals/tsta20 Data-driven exploration of new pressure-induced superconductivity in PbBi2Te4 Ryo Matsumoto, Zhufeng Hou, Masanori Nagao, Shintaro Adachi, Hiroshi Transport measurements Thermoelectric properties, including the electrical resistivity, Seebeck coeﬃcient, and thermal conductiv- ity, were measured by using the thermal transport option (TTO) of physical property measurement sys- tem (PPMS/Quantum Design) under ambient pressure from 300 K to 2 K. The power factor and ﬁgure of merit were evaluated from the obtained parameters. Resistance measurements of PbBi2Te4 single crystal under high pressure were performed using an origin- ally designed DAC with boron-doped diamond elec- trodes [14–17].

ARTICLES PUBLISHED ONLINE: 17 AUGUST 2015 | DOI: 10.1038/NMAT4374 Large-area high-quality 2D ultrathin Mo2C superconducting crystals Chuan Xu1†, Libin Wang2†, Zhibo Liu1, Long Chen1, Jingkun Guo2, Ning Kang2*, Xiu-Liang Ma1, However, the 2D TMCs obtained so far are chemically functionalized, defective nanosheets having maximum lateral dimensions of ∼10 µm. Here we report the fabrication of large-area high-quality 2D ultrathin α-Mo2C crystals by chemical vapour deposition (CVD).

ARTICLES PUBLISHED ONLINE: 17 AUGUST 2015 | DOI: 10.1038/NMAT4374 Large-area high-quality 2D ultrathin Mo2C superconducting crystals Chuan Xu1†, Libin Wang2†, Zhibo Liu1, Long Chen1, Jingkun Guo2, Ning Kang2*, Xiu-Liang Ma1, They show 2D characteristics of superconducting transitions that are consistent with Berezinskii–Kosterlitz–Thouless behaviour and show strong anisotropy with magnetic ﬁeld orientation; moreover, the superconductivity is also strongly dependent on the crystal thickness. Our versatile CVD process allows the fabrication of other high-quality 2D TMC crystals, such as ultrathin WC and TaC crystals, which further expand the large family of 2D materials.

ARTICLES PUBLISHED ONLINE: 17 AUGUST 2015 | DOI: 10.1038/NMAT4374 Large-area high-quality 2D ultrathin Mo2C superconducting crystals Chuan Xu1†, Libin Wang2†, Zhibo Liu1, Long Chen1, Jingkun Guo2, Ning Kang2*, Xiu-Liang Ma1, They have been theoretically predicted or experimentally demonstrated to have many interesting properties, such as highly eﬃcient thermoelectric conversion and electrochemical energy storage8–10. Nevertheless, such chemically derived functionalized 2D TMC sheets are very small, with lateral sizes ranging from hundreds of nanometres to ∼10 µm, suﬀer from severe structural defects, are terminated by hydroxyl and/or other oxygen-containing groups, and have fluorine present on their surface8–12.

ARTICLES PUBLISHED ONLINE: 17 AUGUST 2015 | DOI: 10.1038/NMAT4374 Large-area high-quality 2D ultrathin Mo2C superconducting crystals Chuan Xu1†, Libin Wang2†, Zhibo Liu1, Long Chen1, Jingkun Guo2, Ning Kang2*, Xiu-Liang Ma1, Like other 2D crystals such as graphene, the lack of large-area high-quality 2D TMC crystals has hindered studies of their intrinsic properties. Here we develop a chemical vapour deposition (CVD) process, with methane as the carbon source and a Cu foil sitting on a Mo foil as the substrate at a temperature above 1,085 ◦C, to grow high-quality 2D ultrathin α-Mo2C crystals a few nanometres in thickness with lateral sizes of over 100 µm (see Methods).

ARTICLES PUBLISHED ONLINE: 17 AUGUST 2015 | DOI: 10.1038/NMAT4374 Large-area high-quality 2D ultrathin Mo2C superconducting crystals Chuan Xu1†, Libin Wang2†, Zhibo Liu1, Long Chen1, Jingkun Guo2, Ning Kang2*, Xiu-Liang Ma1, Second, the superconductivity of the ultrathin α-Mo2C crystals is highly reproducible and stable in air for a few months thanks to their excellent thermal and chemical stability. Third, our ultrathin α-Mo2C crystals are fabricated using ambient-pressure CVD, without the requirement of an ultrahigh vacuum, which is diﬀerent from the commonly used molecular beam epitaxial growth method for the fabrication of high-quality 2D superconducting films.

ARTICLES PUBLISHED ONLINE: 17 AUGUST 2015 | DOI: 10.1038/NMAT4374 Large-area high-quality 2D ultrathin Mo2C superconducting crystals Chuan Xu1†, Libin Wang2†, Zhibo Liu1, Long Chen1, Jingkun Guo2, Ning Kang2*, Xiu-Liang Ma1, Such stable high-quality clean 2D superconducting crystals provide not only a new platform to study 2D superconductor physics, but also an ideal building block to assemble with other 2D crystals in the construction of hybrid materials28 or van der Waals heterostructures29 exhibiting possible unusual properties and new phenomena. Importantly, the CVD growth method developed is versatile, and can be used as a general strategy for fabricating a broad class of high- quality 2D ultrathin TMC crystals.

Cava Superconductivity was detected in a compound containing spin ladders by Uehara et al.,4 who measured the resistivity as a function of pressure and temperature in the (Sr142x ,Cax)Cu24O41 compounds. Science and Technology of Advanced Materials ISSN: 1468-6996 (Print) 1878-5514 (Online) Journal homepage: www.tandfonline.com/journals/tsta20 Data-driven exploration of new pressure-induced superconductivity in PbBi2Te4 Ryo Matsumoto, Zhufeng Hou, Masanori Nagao, Shintaro Adachi, Hiroshi The thermoelectric properties of the PbBi2Te4 sample were measured at ambient pressure and the electrical resistance was also evaluated under high pressure using a diamond anvil cell with boron-doped diamond electrodes. The resistance decreased with increasing of the pressure, and pressure-induced superconducting transitions were discovered at 2.5 K under 10 GPa.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the The bottom panel is the powder x-ray diffraction pattern (small circle symbols) compared to a single crystal diffraction pattern (solid line) obtained using an x-ray beam perpendicular to the 00l plane. ducting with a transition temperature Tc of 0.9 ± 0.05 K. Although the zero-ﬁeld data characterize β-IrSn4 well as a s-wave weakly coupled type-I superconductor in a dirty limit, from an estimation of some thermodynamic parameters we arrive at a conclusion that superconductivity in β-IrSn4 can be ascribed to a type-II superconductor in a clean limit with an assumption of a non-spherical Fermi surface.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the In ﬁgure 2(a) we present the temperature dependence of the magnetization M(T) collected at several magnetic ﬁelds. The data at 1.5 mT reveal a large diamagnetic signal below Tc(1.5 mT) = 0.95 K, indicating a superconducting transition.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the In order to get some information on the strength of the electron–phonon coupling we estimate the average electron–phonon coupling constant ¯λe–ph using the McMillan equation [14]: ¯λe–ph = 1.04 + µ∗ln(2D/1.45Tc) (1 −0.62µ∗) ln(2D/1.45Tc) −1.04 (2) where µ∗is the Coulomb pseudopotential, usually assumed to be between 0.1 and 0.15 [14, 15]. For µ∗= 0.15, 2D = 221 K and Tc ≈0.9 K, equation (2) yields ¯λe–ph = 0.5, suggestive of a weak electron–phonon coupling in β-IrSn4.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the The theoretical µ0Hc(T) values have been obtained by integrating the difference of speciﬁc heats between the superconducting (s) and normal (n) state and integrating the difference of the speciﬁc heats divided by temperature according to the formulas: −1 2µ0VMH2 c(T) = 1F(T) = 1U(T) −T1S(T) (3a) 1U(T) = Z Tc T [Cs(T′) −Cn(T′)]d(T′) (3b) 1S(T) = Z Tc T [Cs(T′) −Cn(T′)] T′ d(T′), (3c) where 1U(T) is the internal energy difference and 1S(T) is the entropy difference. Using the relation µ0VH2 c(0) = (3γn/2π2k2 B)(10/kB)2, the values γn = 5.2 × 10−3 J mol−1 K−2, VM = 68.24 × 10−6 m3 mol−1 and 10 = 1.51 K we obtained µ0Hc(0) = 5.76 mT at 0 K. This value is denoted by a solid diamond in ﬁgure 8(b).

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the Another aspect worth considering is the almost linear behavior of Hc2(Tc) above 2 mT. In fact, a ﬁt of the conventional relation Hc2(T) = Hc2(0)[1−(T/Tc(0))n] to the experimental data gives the critical ﬁeld Hc2(0) = 9.55 mT, critical temperature Tc(0) = 1.13 K and exponent n = 1.25.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the We calculated the upper critical ﬁeld using the model developed by Werthamer et al [20] (WHH model) for a type-II superconductor. Taking the slope of µ0Hc2(T) in the temperature range 0.63–0.94 K, dµ0Hc2(T)/dT = −9.83 mT K−1, and the orbital-limiting ﬁeld relation µ0Horb c2 = 0.73Tc(0)[−dµ0Hc2(T)/dT]Tc for a clean limit superconductor, we obtain µ0Horb c2 = 8.1 mT for Tc(0) = 1.13 K. It appears that all observed values of the critical ﬁelds are small and certainly indicate the absence of the Pauli limiting ﬁeld µ0Hp = 1.86Tc, which is of the order of ∼2 T. In order to support the dominant orbital-pair breaking effect we determined the value of the Maki parameter [20, 21], αM = (3e2¯hγVρ0)/(2π2k2 Bme) = 5.4 × 10−3.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the For µ0Hc c = 8.1 mT this results as ξab = 206 nm. Discussion and conclusions The ﬁrst picture which emerges from our measurements on single crystals of β-IrSn4 is that this binary intermetallic compound becomes superconducting below 0.9 ± 0.05 K. The zero-ﬁeld data listed in table 1 are in accordance with the conventional s-wave singlet pairing mechanism and would also provide a hint of either the type-I or type-II/1 superconductivity with a weak electron–phonon coupling.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the Thus, we are dealing with the fact that both RKW and the effective mass of ∼3 me are enhanced in β-IrSn4. Finally, an interesting outcome is obtained from comparison of the studied compound with the intermetallic compound AuSn4, which was previously reported to undergo a superconducting transition at Tc = 2.4 K [26, 27].

Measurements of the magnetic, transport, and thermal properties have been performed.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the Matter 25 (2013) 155701 (8pp) doi:10.1088/0953-8984/25/15/155701 Observation of superconductivity in the intermetallic compound β-IrSn4 Vinh Hung Tran, Zbigniew Bukowski, Piotr Wi´sniewski, Lan Maria Tran and Andrzej J Zaleski Institute of Low Temperature and Structure Research, Polish Academy of Sciences, PO Box 1410, 50-950 Wrocław, Poland E-mail: V.H.Tran@int.pan.wroc.pl Received 4 January 2013, in ﬁnal form 18 February 2013 Published 25 March 2013 Online at stacks.iop.org/JPhysCM/25/155701 Abstract Low-temperature dc-magnetization, ac electrical resistivity and speciﬁc heat measurements were performed on single crystals of the intermetallic compound β-IrSn4. The compound crystallizes in the tetragonal MoSn4-type structure (space group I41/acd) and exhibits superconductivity below Tc = 0.9 ± 0.05 K. Further, the magnitude of the ratios 1Cp/(γnkBTc) = 1.29, 21/(kBTc) = 3.55 and of the electron–phonon coupling λe−ph = 0.5 imply that superconductivity in β-IrSn4 can be ascribed to a s-wave weak coupling regime.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the by an Applied Physics Systems Fluxgate Model 150–6325 magnetometer. Low-temperature data shown in the upper inset of ﬁgure 3(a) indicate that the resistivity starts to drop abruptly at 1 K and arrives at zero value at 0.84 K. The critical temperature, Tc, deﬁned as a middle point of the superconducting transition, and the transition width, 1Tc = Tc(90%) −Tc(10%), are determined to be 0.93 K and 0.15 K, respectively.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the The theoretical µ0Hc(T) values have been obtained by integrating the difference of speciﬁc heats between the superconducting (s) and normal (n) state and integrating the difference of the speciﬁc heats divided by temperature according to the formulas: −1 2µ0VMH2 c(T) = 1F(T) = 1U(T) −T1S(T) (3a) 1U(T) = Z Tc T [Cs(T′) −Cn(T′)]d(T′) (3b) 1S(T) = Z Tc T [Cs(T′) −Cn(T′)] T′ d(T′), (3c) where 1U(T) is the internal energy difference and 1S(T) is the entropy difference. Using the relation µ0VH2 c(0) = (3γn/2π2k2 B)(10/kB)2, the values γn = 5.2 × 10−3 J mol−1 K−2, VM = 68.24 × 10−6 m3 mol−1 and 10 = 1.51 K we obtained µ0Hc(0) = 5.76 mT at 0 K. This value is denoted by a solid diamond in ﬁgure 8(b).

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the A comparison of the calculated thermodynamic critical ﬁelds at 0 and 1.5 mT indicates that the temperature dependence of µ0Hc(T) is sensitive to applied magnetic ﬁelds. A remarkable ﬁnding of our measurements is that Tc(Hc2) = 0.85 K at zero ﬁeld attains its maximum value of 0.94 K in ﬁelds 1.5 and 2 mT.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the A comparison of the calculated thermodynamic critical ﬁelds at 0 and 1.5 mT indicates that the temperature dependence of µ0Hc(T) is sensitive to applied magnetic ﬁelds. A remarkable ﬁnding of our measurements is that Tc(Hc2) = 0.85 K at zero ﬁeld attains its maximum value of 0.94 K in ﬁelds 1.5 and 2 mT.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the Another aspect worth considering is the almost linear behavior of Hc2(Tc) above 2 mT. In fact, a ﬁt of the conventional relation Hc2(T) = Hc2(0)[1−(T/Tc(0))n] to the experimental data gives the critical ﬁeld Hc2(0) = 9.55 mT, critical temperature Tc(0) = 1.13 K and exponent n = 1.25.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the For µ0Hc c = 8.1 mT this results as ξab = 206 nm. Discussion and conclusions The ﬁrst picture which emerges from our measurements on single crystals of β-IrSn4 is that this binary intermetallic compound becomes superconducting below 0.9 ± 0.05 K. The zero-ﬁeld data listed in table 1 are in accordance with the conventional s-wave singlet pairing mechanism and would also provide a hint of either the type-I or type-II/1 superconductivity with a weak electron–phonon coupling.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the Thus, we are dealing with the fact that both RKW and the effective mass of ∼3 me are enhanced in β-IrSn4. Finally, an interesting outcome is obtained from comparison of the studied compound with the intermetallic compound AuSn4, which was previously reported to undergo a superconducting transition at Tc = 2.4 K [26, 27].

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the To summarize, we have grown single crystals of inter- metallic compound β-IrSn4, crystallizing in the tetragonal MoSn4-type structure. We found a superconducting transition Tc(0T) = 0.9 ± 0.05 K and an upper critical magnetic ﬁeld µ0Hc2(0) ∼8 mT.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER In this respect, Re24Ti5 would provide an opportunity to search for the existence of a mixture of spin singlet and spin triplet states in the SC phase of the noncentrosymmetric compounds. In this paper, we report on the synthesis and charac- terization of Re24Ti5, which exhibits a distinct bulk SC transition at Tc ≃5.8 K. Measurements of the magnetic, transport, and thermal properties have been performed.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility for Re24Ti5 is shown in ﬁgure 2. The observed diamagnetic behavior below the transition temperature Tc ≃ 5.8 K conﬁrms the occurrence of superconductivity in this material.
